review.title: Attacker and Defender Counting Approach for Abstract Argumentation
review.abstract: In Dung's abstract argumentation, arguments are either acceptable or unacceptable, given a chosen notion of acceptability. This gives a coarse way to compare arguments. In this paper, we propose a counting approach for a more fine-gained assessment to arguments by counting the number of their respective attackers and defenders based on argument graph and argument game. An argument is more acceptable if the proponent puts forward more number of defenders for it and the opponent puts forward less number of attackers against it. We show that our counting model has two well-behaved properties: normalization and convergence. Then, we define a counting semantics based on this model, and investigate some general properties of the semantics.

sections.heading: Attacker and Defender Counting Semantics
sections.text: In classical abstract reasoning, arguments are either acceptable or unacceptable based on a chosen notion of acceptance, which gives a fairly rough way to compare arguments. In this essay, we intend to provide a more fine-grained evaluation of arguments based on the graph structure of the reasoning system. Our basic starting point is that argument x is more acceptable than argument y iff PRO more defenders for x and OPP less attackers against x.For such an idea, our approach is to count the number of attackers and defenders for each argument. The fewer attackers and the more defenders an argument has, the more acceptable the argument is. In this approach, the main limitation is that we must be able to identify all attackers and defenders for each argument, which is quite simple in the case of argument graphs without cycles. In this section, we will first introduce a matrix approach to record and track all attackers and defenders of varying lengths for each argument, regardless of whether the argument graph is acyclic or cyclic.
